captions.text:
If you take a piece of wood and put it next
to another piece of wood... nothing happens.

And if you take a piece of granite and put
it next to another rock... still nothing.

But if you take this piece of iron and put
it next to this other piece of iron... magic!
I mean, magnet.

Magnetic objects are able to magically attract
at long distance because they generate magnetic

fields that extend invisibly out beyond the
object. But the mystery is this: where do
magnetic fields come from?

Derek: well that's easy, Henry! We've known
for a long time that electricity and magnetism

are really just two sides of the same coin,
kind of like mass and energy or time and space,

and they can be transformed into each other.
In fact, magnetic fields are basically just

what electric fields turn into when an electrically
charged object starts moving!

Henry: That makes sense for explaining why
a current of electrons flowing through a wire

causes this compass needle to move, or how
currents in the earth's outer core generate

the geomagnetic field... but a bar magnet
or the compass needle itself are just pieces

of metal without any electrical current running
through them.

Derek: Or are they? At a microscopic level,
there are loads of electrons whizzing around

in the atoms and molecules that make up any
solid.

Henry: Right! This brings up an excellent
point - The magnetic behavior of any everyday

object is influenced by a fascinating combination
of effects ranging from the level of particles

to atoms, collections of atoms, and collections
of collections of atoms. First, individual
particles.

Unlike the everyday workings of gravity and
electricity, permanent magnets can only be

fully understood as a quantum mechanical effect.
In much the same way that particles like electrons

and quarks have fundamental properties called
mass and electrical charge, most particles

ALSO have another intrinsic property, called
"tiny magnet". Just kidding, it's called an

"intrinsic magnetic moment," but really, that's
just technical mumbo-jumbo saying that particles

with electric charge ALSO happen to be tiny
magnets.

Derek: If you want to know WHY they're tiny
magnets, well, you might as well ask WHY do

particles have charge in the first place,
or why do objects with energy and momentum

attract gravitationally? No one knows... We
just know these things are true/that is how
the universe works.

Henry: Exactly, and since the 1920s, we've
known that each individual electron or proton

is basically a tiny magnet. Which brings us
to the level of atoms.

An atom is a bunch of positively charged protons
with a bunch of negatively charged electrons

whizzing around them. The proton tiny magnets
are about 1000 times weaker than the electron

ones, so the nucleus of the atom has almost
no effect on the magnetism of the atom as
a whole.

Derek: And you might think that since many
(though not all) of the electrons are also

moving, like the current in a wire, they would
generate magnetic fields from that motion.

Indeed they do, and these are called "orbital"
magnetic fields.

Henry: Except, these don't usually contribute
to the magnetic field of an atom. Here's why:

Electrons in atoms are accurately and complicatedly
described by quantum mechanics, but the gist

of the story is that electrons congregate
in shells around the nucleus. The electrons

in any filled shell zoom equally in all directions
and so the currents they generate cancel out

and generate no magnetic field. These electrons
also come in pairs whose tiny magnets point
in opposite directions and also cancel.

However, in a half-filled shell, all of the
electrons are unpaired and their tiny magnets

point in the same direction and add up, meaning
that it's the intrinsic magnetism of the electrons

in the outer shell that gives an atom the
majority of its magnetic field.

So atoms near the side of any of the major
blocks of the periodic table, which have full

(or nearly full) outer electron shells, aren't
very magnetic. And atoms in the MIDDLE of

the blocks have half-full outer electron shells
and are magnetic. For example, Nickel, Cobalt,
Iron, Manganese, Chromium, etc.
Derek: Wait, but chromium isn't magnetic!

Henry: Ah, but just because an atom is magnetic
doesn't mean that a material made up of lots

of that atom will be magnetic. Which brings
us to the level of crystals.

When a bunch of magnetic atoms get together
to make a solid, they generally have two options.

One is for all of the atoms to align their
magnetic fields with each other, or they can

align the magnetic fields in an alternating
fashion so that they all cancel out. The atoms
will do whichever one requires less energy.

Derek: That's why chromium, for example, is
a very magnetic atom but a very un-magnetic

solid - because it's one of the most anti-ferromagnetic
materials we know. Iron, on the other hand,

is the name-sake of ferromagnetism, so it
is, unsurprisingly, ferromagnetic. Or, in
usual parlance: magnetic.
Henry: Sometimes.

The last and final level of magnetism is that
of domains. Essentially, even in a magnetic

material where the magnetic fields of atoms
line up together, it's possible that one chunk

of the material will have all its atoms lined
up pointing one way, and another chunk will

have all its atoms pointing another way, and
so on.

Derek: If all of these "Domains" are of approximately
similar size, none may be strong enough to

force the others to align with it, and so
a piece of iron, for example, might have no

magnetic field because of all of the warring
magnetic kingdoms within it.

Henry: However, if you apply a strong enough
magnetic field/force/pressure from outside

the material, you can help favor one domain/help
one domain expand its control over its neighbors,

and so on until all of the domains have been
unified into one kingdom, all pointing in
the same direction.

Derek : And now, finally, you can rule with
an iron fist... I mean, magnet.

Henry: Exactly! What's remarkable is that
magnetism is a fundamentally quantum property

amplified to the size of everyday objects:
every permanent magnet is a reminder that

quantum mechanics underlies our universe - in
order for any object to be magnetic, it has

to have a unified kingdom of magnetic domains,
each made up of bajillions of magnetic atoms

which also need to be aligned with each other,
each of which can only be magnetic in the

first place if it has an approximately half-filled
outer shell of electrons so their intrinsic

magnetic fields can align and not cancel each
other out. Not surprisingly, these criteria

are pretty difficult to fulfill, which is
why there are only a limited number of suitable

materials you can use when you're building
a magnet.

Derek: OR you could just run a current through
any electrical conductor and generate a magnetic

field that way.
Henry: But hey... Why does that work in the

first place? Click here to go to over to Veritasium
and we'll find out what special relativity
and the speed of light have to do with electromagnets.

comments.text:
+Chris K I think there's a mistake because your post says you're replying 
to +Laszlo Szabo.

Otherwise, thank you for your clarification.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo"I didn't say 'physicists need to solve it!' I said the 
statement is wrong and that is all I said."

Initially, I thought you meant that that it should be the job of 
physicists. I understand you now, and I'm sorry for misinterpreting you.

"I can't keep up with this. I can't tell which physicists you're talking 
about."

I was quite sick when I wrote my previous post and am sorry for any poor 
wording or confusion that I caused. The point of my post was that since it 
is not considered the job of physicists to explain that (almost) none of 
the mainstream physicists are trying to do it. For clarification, I was 
referring to the majority of them, but not all.

I will try to word this better: Too few physicists are trying to actually 
explain the mechanisms of the universe. Most of them are satisfied with 
performing mathematics alone.

I was also trying to give you my own personal opinion on the matter which 
is that it should also be the job of physicists to explain. Being a student 
of mathematics and physics myself, I do not hold the same opinion as the 
majority. When they say it is the job of ONLY philosophers to explain, they 
are trying to pass their job off to someone else.

My question to them is this: Why is it that in all other branches of 
science it is required to explain an event, but in physics it is not?

I understand that maybe you don't even care about my opinion, but I felt 
the need to give it anyway since it is relevant to your post.
comments.author: Chris K

comments.text:
+Nikhil Vetam, everything is great, except one point:

*trying to measure a phenomenon with limited knowledge is definitely not 
going to give us right answer.*

This is false. Just because we have limited knowledge, it doesn't mean we 
don't know, or cannot know, or not get us a right answer about something 
non-empirical. Our knowledge is limited, yes. But we're infinitely smarter 
than a rock. We may not know everything *about* the answer, but we can 
still know the actual right answer.

Consider this example:

*What is 1 foofoolaa + 1 foofoolaa?*

Well, we don't know what a foofoolaa is (I just made it up), but we know 
with certainty what the right answer is. And this is outside of physics, 
and into philosophy (math is deduction, which falls under philosophy).

This is similar to what Cashman9111 said above who got angry and said this 
before he left:

*"let's say there is a reason for that... something existing independent of 
itself, right ? what's next ? what does that independence mean, what is the 
point ?"*
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:
+Yousef Shanawany To your "this is just is" thing, I also feel that it's a 
worst way avoid difficult explanations. Also, what you said about that not 
just being Physics and now a question of philosophy also means that, trying 
to measure a phenomenon with limited knowledge is definitely not going to 
give us right answer. May be it's even beyond Physics & Philosophy both. 
I'm also eagerly waiting for satisfactory explanation.
comments.author: Nikhil Vetam

comments.text:
Hello +Nikhil Vetam, I wish you well.

The point I was trying to make is that there is a reason for magnetic 
fields' existence, and saying "it just is" is wrong, as the video and some 
users stated. We aren't concluding that fairies is the reason, nor that 
electrons had their own consciousness is the reason. Whether these are true 
or false is a good discussion elsewhere. I was only concluding that there 
*is* a reason. Whether the reason is faries, or electrons having 
consciousness, these all conclude that there is an actual reason.

If we want to go further than that, and ask the question: "Why did the 
conscious entity (whether fairies, conscious electrons, etc.) choose that 
magnets should *attract* rather than *retract*?", we are still concluding 
that there is a reason. Because a conscious entity's decisions are made 
using reasoning. When something is *chosen*, the word "chosen" implies a 
reason for something being picked.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.author: Laszlo Szabo

comments.text:
+Chris K, I don't know what happened to you. You were friendly and 
discussing kindly, but now there's ignorance in your post all of the sudden.

First, you said that *most* physicists don't know philosophy. Then you said *literally 
no one* knows physics and philosophy. Then you said *in general*, 
physicists don't know philosophy. Now you are saying in capital letters: *NONE 
of them* explain physics and philosophy. Now you are also saying 
*university* physicists don't know philosophy. I can't keep up with this. I 
can't tell which physicists you're talking about.

Second, when I said *"And this does make sense because physics is the study 
of HOW the Universe works, and not the WHY,"* this is not my 'thought' as 
you said above. This is the definition of physics. Taken from dictionary.com: 
physics: *"the **science** that deals with matter, energy, motion, and 
force."* So when you told me *"If you think this is so"*, I can't reply to 
that because it's not an opinion. I'm talking about physics... not my own 
interpretation of physics.

Third, you then asked me why I was concerned with "it just is" being a lazy 
cop out. This doesn't have to do with my definition of physicists. I'm not 
arguing that physicists are at fault. This is a misrepresentation of me 
again. I'm saying the video is wrong with the statement "it just is." 
Whether the people in the video were physicists or philosophers, the answer 
is still wrong. I didn't say 'physicists need to solve it!' I said the 
statement is wrong and that is all I said.

Then you said that the physicists I researched who were knowledgeable in 
philosophy were only the greatest in their field who contributed greatly. 
Chris... you don't know who I've researched and who I didn't research. You 
know each physicists I've researched. So you can't say this my friend. You 
can't tell me about the physicists I've researched and if they contributed 
in my field. I can tell you, however. But you can not tell me my physicists 
because you don't know who they are.

Also, even if this is true (that the physicists I've researched are only 
the ones who contributed greatly and were the top physicists), then this 
shows that there do exists physicists that know philosophy, because you 
said earlier that *NONE* of the physicists explain the WHY (aka philosophy).

Also, many of your statements begin with the phrase: "According to me." 
This doesn't benefit me because, according to them, physicists don't need 
philosophy (if your statement about them is true). If you have evidence, 
then that should be posted here. Opinions have little-to-no argument value.

Whether physicists should be required to take philosophy or not is a 
different discussion. I was only saying that they are not allowed to say 
"it just is" because that statement is false.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:
"But I think it is true that popular physicists and media-skilled 
physicists don't explain and only describe..."

NONE of them explain! Explanations are not what is taught as standardized 
university physics. The only thing you will hear out of the current 
mainstream are equations and descriptions (or HOW) -- nothing else. And the 
theories which are trying to be passed off as explanations are still not 
explanations. Once again, this is because they do not understand the 
difference between the two. They think math explains -- it does NOT.

"And this does make sense because physics is the study of HOW the Universe 
works, and not the WHY."

If you think this is so, then why are you saying the statement "it just is" 
is a lazy cop-out? If its not the physicists job to tell us why (explain), 
then they need not be concerned with it.

According to ME, they should be asking the WHY questions as well, but they 
do NOT in modern physics. And this is exactly why we are now in this 
current situation of not understanding the way things work -- just as you 
yourself pointed out earlier.

"But the more books and articles I read, and the more physicists I research 
who are not known commonly, the more I see they had knowledge of both."

These are only the ones who were the greatest in their field -- the cutting 
edge guys who contributed to the field greatly. We're talking like a dozen 
guys out of thousands. A degree in physics nowadays requires little to no 
philosophy whatsoever. According to me, certain philosophy and logic 
courses should become standard requirement in physics and all of science 
for that matter. This would prevent us from leading to logical 
contradictions like "beginning of time", Copenhagen Interpretation, etc.

Contrary to popular belief, there is not one "mainstream" physicist who can 
explain how a magnet works, or how gravity works, or light, or anything for 
that matter.

Anyone arguing in favor of the currently proposed theories (i.e. 
Relativity, Higgs Field, Newtonian, etc.) does not understand that they 
don't explain anything -- they describe. But, physics should be doing a lot 
more than that.

Otherwise, we will keep getting the same irritating "it just is" statements 
that you and I are arguing against.
comments.author: Chris K

comments.text:
+Chris K

I still disagree with the the statement that most physicists lacking 
philosophical knowledge. However, I do agree that most physicists I see on 
YouTube, TV, and the majority of media-skilled physicists have a bad 
understanding of philosophical concepts. But the more books and articles I 
read, and the more physicists I research who are not known commonly, the 
more I see they had knowledge of both. Maybe (and this is just a theory) 
the media is trying to hide these philosophical-smart physicists. Barns and 
Noble may be hiding them from us. For the media, I think you're right. But 
I am finding out otherwise.

I also don't agree that there are very few people on this Earth who are 
actually trying to explain the mechanisms of the Universe. I think you're 
saying that most of the physicists explain the HOW of the mechanisms of the 
Universe, and not the WHY, where the *how* is the description, and the *why* 
is the explanation. And this does make sense because physics is the study 
of HOW the Universe works, and not the WHY. That's what physics is. But I 
think it is true that *popular* physicists and media-skilled physicists 
don't explain and only describe... 

But the more books / articles I read, the more I find out that the WHY of 
the mechanisms of the Universe was dealt with by many physicists, and those 
physicists who had philosophical knowledge had a lot of fun messing with 
these non-philosophical physicists (like Isaac Newton and Erwin 
Schrödinger). They would keep posing these philosophical problems to the 
non-philosophical physicists, and reading their stories of how they poked 
at these non-philosophical physicists is fun.

However, these are just my experience on my research. If there is authentic 
statistics or something, it would be a good read and we can get closer to 
the answer.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo The interpretations of quantum mechanics are actually 
numerous and many physicists are in disagreement. You must be getting only 
some of them -- more than likely the Copenhagen or Many Worlds 
interpretations as they seem to be the most popular. Personally, I don't 
agree with either of them.

I actually created a theory a few years back and it seems others out there 
had similar ideas for quantum behaviors. Recent experiments have shown 
evidence for a pilot wave theory to at least partially explain the 
double-slit experiments.

http://www.wired.com/2014/06/the-new-quantum-reality/
comments.author: Chris K

comments.text:
+Yousef Shanawany You make a great point, and there were definitely some 
great thinking physicists who were also philosophers. Perhaps my wording 
was poor. What I meant to say is that MOST physicists (especially nowadays) 
are completely inept at the subject of philosophy. You made examples of a 
few, but this is nowhere near representative of the majority. In other 
words, many physicists today cannot grasp even the most basic of logic. You 
are experiencing this right now! And believe me, you will continue 
experiencing it.

Also, I should not have stated "literally", but it is true that there are 
very few people on this entire Earth who are actually trying to EXPLAIN the 
mechanisms of the universe. What the physicists do nowadays is description 
(primarily in the form of mathematics). Unfortunately, most of them do not 
understand the difference between a description and an explanation. Solving 
algebra and calculus equations is fine and necessary but does not actually 
EXPLAIN the mechanisms. Mathematics merely restates observations in its own 
language.

I also agree that saying "it just is" is running away from the problem. I 
thought I made that clear in my previous post. However, it does seem as 
though I looked too far into your post and assumed you were looking for the 
answer -- you may or may not be, but I get your point now.
comments.author: Chris K

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo, a couple of problems here:

1. Consider a case where both cannot happen, such as a planet staying still 
and moving at the same time in the same way. By saying both can happen, 
such a person is now shutting off their logic and is now willing to accept 
anything ever. If we accept that something can be moving and not moving at 
the same time, than what is stopping us from illogical claims, such as one 
claiming they drew a 4-sided triangle? This is not logical and we reject 
such a claim.

Even if this results in the multiverse mentioned above, there's still 
problems here:

2. Saying a multiverse is the solution is running away as this is never 
provable. It's not the only solution to the problem in the video... so why 
do we jump to that conclusion and not any other answer, such as saying 
there was a reason for its existence? We should use common sense and say 
that contradictions do not exist in the Universe, and such a case cannot 
exist. Something cannot be dead and alive at the same time. Saying a 
multiverse is something not provable, so the one making the claim is not 
certain of his answer and should be questioned as to why they chose that 
answer over any other answer.

3. Even if the solution is a multiverse, this still gives us more questions 
than answers. Like, if a cat was alive and dead at the same time, and you 
saw the dead cat in this Universe we are in right now, then this brings the 
question again... why do you see a dead cat in this Universe and not the 
live one? In the current Universe, if you opened the box, you only see 1 
outcome. Not both. Both outcomes cannot happen in 1 Universe. You will only 
see one outcome.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:
+Yousef Shanawany if chances don't truly exist than random doesn't exist 
either, im just saying that i dont find the notion of both existing insane. 
if we dont know why the laws of the universe are what they are than we 
can't be completely sure if they are the same in every scale.
comments.author: Laszlo Szabo

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo As we've agreed earlier, random, as we use it today, is an 
estimation. This is as you said (and I agreed with you):

*"we say a certain thing has x% chance of happening because we dont know 
all the factors dictating what is going to happen, and all we can do is 
guess."* - Apr 18, 2015

*the concept of random is that one outcome will happen instead of the other 
without a reason other that "it is random both can happen"*
In an estimated random from human estimation, then yes. But in an actual 
random, then no. Because if one happened over the others, then it wasn't 
actually random in the first place.

*i also dont think that chances truly exist, but the multiverse theory is a 
valid explanation to randomness.*
Randomness is saying that chances truly exist. But if you don't think 
chances truly exist, than random doesn't truly exist.
comments.author: Yousef Shanawany (AskYous)

comments.text:

comments.author: Laszlo Szabo

comments.text:

comments.author: Laszlo Szabo

comments.text:
+Laszlo Szabo, yes. There are many interpretations. Scientists began to 
conclude a multi-verse reality does exist. When we check the box, we may 
see the cat alive (for example). But, if the reaction was truly random, 
another Universe now exists where the cat is dead. This is as stated on 
Wikipedia:

*" The cat is both alive and dead— **regardless of whether the box is 
opened** —but the "alive" and "dead" cats are in different branches of the 
universe that are equally real but cannot interact with each other."* - 
Wikipedia (http://goo.gl/LsZl5i)

But regardless of the different interpretations, if the reaction was truly 
random, then one outcome cannot exist. Either all the outcomes must happen, 
or none, because they all had the same change of happening. If one of them 
happened and not the others, than there was a reason for that one happening.

comments.author: Brian Turner

comments.text:
Is that really the answer that you expect, when you ask how magnets work?
"Why"-questions can always be answered in multiple correct ways, of which 
many are not satisfactory. "How"-questions are probably similar.

What is the motivation of a kid that asks "How do magnets work?"?
I suppose it really wants to know if the magnetic effect can be explained 
by other forces which produce movement - it already knows 
"pushing"/mechanical force and gravity.

(In this case the answer could be: There is no invisible stuff that 
connects the magnets. We just call things that can pull each other without 
connections "magnets". Everything with weight pulls everything else a 
little bit - you only notice it with things that are as heavy as a planet: 
That is called "gravity". Magnets can pull noticeably when they are small 
like a pinhead.)

I'm not saying the video isn't true or interesting.

Why do children ask why the sky is blue but not why tomatoes are red?﻿

comments.author: farjacko

comments.text:
Wow.

First, we were discussing permanent magnets, not electromagnets.
Second, if a magnetic field is a wave, as you say, then through what medium 
does that wave propagate?
Third, gravity has nothing to do with atomic nuclei - the repulsive force 
of having so many protons in so small a space should blow it apart, but the 
strong nuclear force binds it together.
Fourth, gravitational force is technically a measurement of the distortion 
of the Higgs field, as affected by particles possessing a Higgs boson, and 
not related to magnetic fields.

If you're going to belittle someone with science, make sure you're actually 
the smartest guy in the room first.

You were, however, correct in that a liquid metallic core is a good 
indication of a magnetic field in a celestial body.

comments.author: DStray Cat

comments.text:
+DStray Cat We clearly detect that there's something we aren't accounting 
for in the universe when it comes to the mass. So, for the time being we've 
given this unknown substance the names "dark matter & dark energy" until 
more data comes in. They're just temporary place holder names in order to 
refer to the yet unknown substance(s). The word "dark" references the fact 
this mysterious hypothetical substance doesn't reflect or emit visible or 
non-visible light. The words "matter" and "energy" are just general 
scientific words for the colloquial "stuff", for literally every physical 
thing in the natural universe that we know of is made of some combination 
of matter and energy. Thus, "dark matter" and "dark energy" are merely 
science talk for "unknown, undetectable, hypothetical substance". So what's 
wrong with scientists being humble and saying there seems to be something 
there but we don't know what it is yet? Seems reasonable to me. What would 
you rather them proclaim? That they know exactly what it is and list all 
its properties? That would be lying for we don't know that information 
quite yet.
